results.title: Quiz show
results.creator_credit: Robert Redford, Michael Nozik, Julian Krainin, Michael Jacobs and Hollywood Pictures
results.brief_description: Ralph Fiennes and John Turturro play contestants battling for huge cash prizes and instant fame on a top-rated quiz show in the mid-1950s. When charges surface that the hit program is fixed and players are being given the answers, it becomes far more than a game. Contestants, producers and the network itself get caught in the centre of an escalating scandal. Nominated for the 1994 Best Picture Academy Award and based on a true story that shocked the United States, this is a very compelling film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Redford, Michael Nozik, Julian Krainin, Michael Jacobs and Hollywood Pictures

results.title: Quintet
results.creator_credit: Robert Altman and Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation
results.brief_description: Robert Altman’s “Quintet” was received with almost universal derision when it was released in 1979. He had made his reputation with very contemporary, very insisive and very American films. “Quintet” is strikingly different: heavily symbolic, with a mannerist visual palette, it was a departure for Altman and sees him explore themes associated with European existentialism. In a desolate future Ice-Age the remaining inhabitants of Earth are facing their extinction. Paul Newman plays a hunter, returning to his birthplace, accompanied by a pregnant woman (a startling occurrence in a world where most people are no longer able to reproduce). Her murder leads him to a confrontation with the players of Quintet, an elaborate and violent game which is the main activity of the future. As he becomes more involved in the strategies and rules of Quintet, he finds himself losing his identity. This complex and philosophical science-fiction film, creates a future as it may have been envisaged by Kafka and is a uniquely original meditation on the struggle and meaning of human “free will”. Undeniably difficult and ambitious, the film deserves a more serious critical engagement than that offered by contemporary English-language critics. Also stars Vittorio Gassman, Bibi Anderson and Fernando Rey.

results.title: Quintessence: five short films by Barry J. Hershey
results.creator_credit: Barry J Hersey and Waldon Woods Film
results.brief_description: This meditative exploration by filmmaker Barry J. Hersey presents life in a visual poetry. Themes of life, birth, death and spirit fill each piece. Form and substance are explored. Reality and art are questioned as we journey through the spiritually observant eyes of the filmmaker. Each piece reveals the different and crucial aspects of the human condition and the place or insignificance of a person on earth. The nature and contours of the landscape are seen through new eyes while the suggestive ocean offers deeper interpretations of the world around us. The filmmaker makes use of the effects that music has on the visual experience with dreamy and relaxing sounds unifying the meditative aspects of this style of filmmaking.

results.title: Quilts in women's lives
results.creator_credit: Pat Ferrero and New Day Films
results.brief_description: A multi-award winning film on the traditional art of quiltmaking and its affect on the lives of seven women. Each from quite diverse backgrounds, the women discuss the influences that inspire quilt design, and how their lives and times are depicted in their work.

results.title: Quills
results.creator_credit: Philip Kaufman, Nick Wechsler, Peter Kaufman, Julia Chasma, Walrus and Associates, Industry Entertainment, Hollywood Partners and Fox Searchlight Pictures
results.brief_description: Paris, 1804 - following the bloody climate of the French Revolution erotic writer, the Marquis de Sade, resides in the Charenton Asylum for the insane where he continues to pen his sadomasochistic literature. When his latest tome upsets Napoleon, Dr Royer-Collard (Michael Caine) is despatched to ensure that de Sade be published no more. In charge of the asylum is a benevolent priest Coulmier (Joaquin Phoenix) who allows de Sade’s writings as a form of therapy. Coulmier and Royer-Collard soon come into conflict about the treatment of the Marquis and the running of the asylum. But the priest faces a greater challenge - his lust for a common laundress sparks suppressed desires, but it is she who is sneaking out the Marquis’ incendiary prose. Meanwhile the doctor marries a virginal bride, brought up in a nunnery, who he mercilessly abuses. Philip Kaufman (The Unbearable lightness of being, Henry and June, The Right stuff) presents the Marquis de Sade as a mostly harmless presence (ignoring his historical squalidity) - compared to the enshrined corruption within the Church. Kaufman ably captures the fetid environs of the asylum; the barely contained carnal desires of the inmates, their depravity and insanity, inflaming the nightmarish atmosphere of these scenes. Rush puts in an impressive, if manic, performance as a tormented artist, whose prose may inspire acts of passion and murder witnessed throughout the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Philip Kaufman, Nick Wechsler, Peter Kaufman, Julia Chasma, Walrus and Associates, Industry Entertainment, Hollywood Partners and Fox Searchlight Pictures

results.title: Quill
results.creator_credit: Jo Kennedy and Victorian College of the Arts
results.brief_description: A woman’s desire to write is literally inscribed onto her body when her breasts begin to leak ink. Cast includes Sally Cooper, Belinda McCory.

results.title: Quigley
results.creator_credit: Simon Wincer, Alex Rose, Stanley O'Toole and Pathe Entertainment
results.brief_description: Tom Selleck stars as Matthew Quigley, an American hired gun who answers a “Help Wanted” ad and finds himself in Australia. Alan Rickman plays the evil, British cattle rancher who hires Quigley. Quigley refuses the job and is left stranded in the outback with a crazy woman called Cora (Laura San Giacomo). Essentially a western in an outback setting, the film also features Chris Haywood, Tony Bonner and Ben Mendelson.

results.title: Quiet please
results.brief_description: SUMMARY: An explanation of what noise is, where it most commonly occurs, how it affects the human body, and what can be done to reduce or eliminate it by industry and research laboratories

results.title: Quiet man with welding torch: a portrait of sculptor Julio Gonzalez 1876-1942
results.creator_credit: Barrie Gavin, William Leeson, Laurence Boulting, Waveband Film Productions and RM Arts
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
The spanish artist Julio Gonzalez (1876-1942) has been recognised along with Brancusi and Picasso as one of the most important sculptors of the 20th Century in his generation responsible for ‘opening the most doors for 20th century sculpture’. A man of acute sensibilities whose ‘aesthetics of poverty’ gave birth to a legacy that celebrated found junk-metal and iron scraps making elegant and poignant sculptural forms. The documentary examines the sculptors past as jeweller and his growing aesthetic and technical methods throughout his career. A fearful man who lived a simple life away from publicity and the art world after the volatile period surrounding the world wars in Europe and the Spanish civil war. Narrated by Lyndon Brook.
